monogr.title: Melancholike humours, in verses of diuerse natures, set downe by Nich: Breton, Gent
monogr.author: Breton, Nicholas

div.head: ¶ To the Reader.
div.p:
PASQVILL, hauing been long in his dumps, in somewhat better then a browne studie, hath brought forth the fruites of a fewe melancholike humours: which chiefely he commendeth to spirits of his own nature, full of melancholy, and as neere Bedlem, as Mooregate; a figure in the fields to be easily disciphered. To be short, and to growe towards an ende, ere I haue wel begun, I wil tel you; the gētlemās brains were much troubled, as you may see by his perplexities: but with studying how to make one line leuell with another, in more rime then perhaps some will thinke reason, with much adoe about nothing, hee hath made a piece of worke as little worth. He that can giue him less • commendation, let him vse his arte. For mine owne part, I haue taken paine to write his Will, which he hath sent to the worlde to like as it list. According to whose
will, I leaue it; entreating no man to wreste his will to any thing, further then may stand with his pleasure; but to speake indifferently of all things, as hee findes cause: and so I rest
